How U.K. And Royals Will Virtually Celebrate Landmark VE-Day, May 8

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

How U.K. And Royals Will Virtually Celebrate Landmark VE-Day, May 8

The message the world had been waiting for was brilliantly to the point. Shortly after German officials signed the first documents of surrender in Reims, France (additional papers were formalized in Berlin the next day), ending the fighting in Europe, General Dwight Eisenhower, Supreme Allied Command, notified his chiefs of staff: “The mission of this Allied Force was fulfilled at 0241, local time, May 7th, 1945.” While the Second World War would not come to a final close until Japan’s surrender in August, the end of hostilities on the continent was marked by an outbreak of celebrations in many countries and no where more enthusiastically than in London, where thousands flocked to the streets and to well-known monuments like Buckingham Palace, Parliament and Piccadilly Circus. [To get a better understanding of Britain’s precarious first months during the war, read Erik Larson’s riveting The Splendid and the Vile, which recently topped The New York Times’ non-fiction best seller list.] “In all our long history, we have never seen a greater day than this,” Winston Churchill said when he appeared before exuberant throngs at the Ministry of Health in Whitehall. The U.K. had hoped for a full-out celebration this year to mark the 75th anniversary of VE Day; because of the pandemic all events will be virtual with individual observances taking place at home. But there are plenty of online and televised happenings to commemorate the date and honor veterans and the sacrifices made during the war. The U.K’s Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said in a statement: “In these difficult times, acts of remembrance are even more poignant and I am sure that millions will want to join me to remember and give thanks to those who gave so much to secure peace, freedom and prosperity in Europe.” Here are some of the major events planned. For additional information go to VE-VJDay75.gov.uk.  At 11 AM, a Two Minute Silence will be observed in the U.K. At 11:15 there will be a VE Day 75 Livestreamhosted by the Royal British Legion. For details, click here. Queen Elizabeth’s address to the country will be aired at 9 PM, May 8, on BBC One, the time her father, King George VI, spoke to a jubilant Britain 75 years earlier. Prince Charles will commemorate VE Day 75 by reading from his grandfather’s diary entry for the day, which included the historic appearance on the balcony of Buckingham Palace with Winston Churchill. Video chats will take place between members of the royal family and veterans. Winston Churchill’s victory speech will be broadcast by the BBC during the program, VE Day 75: The Announcement Of Victory, starting at 2:45 PM. In the evening another special, VE Day 75: The People’s Celebration, begins at 8PM. After the Queen’s message at 9 PM, the show will end with a nationwide singing of the WWII classic, “We’ll Meet Again,” made famous by Dame Vera Lynn. For a schedule of additional VE Day television and radio programs planned by the BBC, click here. ITV will have a program devoted to the U.K’s remarkable Captain (now honorary Colonel) Tom Moore, a British Army and WWII veteran who has recently gained international acclaim for raising more than £30 million for the country’s National Health Service charities by walking 100 laps in his garden. (Moore turned 100 on April 30.) The Royal Air Force Museum, National Army Museum and the National Museum of the Royal Navy are presenting a Virtual VE Day 75 Festival, from May 7-9, that will include a webinar with top historian James Holland and curators from the museums, along with presentations highlighting experiences both at home and on the front lines during the Second World War And you can time travel with vintage recipes and music. If you’re frustrated because of the shortages of certain foods during the Covid-19 pandemic, consider that rationing in the U.K.began in 1940 (to see a ration list, go to Historic UK) and continued until 1954. For at-home VE Day celebrations, there are items popular during the Second World War, when cooks had to do a lot with little, that you can make. English Heritage has a party pack that includes recipes for carrot scones and ginger beer. The VE-VJDay75.gov.org site has various assets you can download for a party, like bunting templates and posters, along with recipes for dishes like Homity Pie and an eggless fruit cake. There’s also a Spotify playlist with music from the era with such names as Frank Sinatra, Glenn Miller and Vera Lynn.

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/catherinesabino/2020/05/03/how-uk-and-royals-will-virtually-celebrate-landmark-ve-day-may-8/
Rating: 4.41

The Best Ways To Get A Nintendo Switch Right Now

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

The Best Ways To Get A Nintendo Switch Right Now

Update, 5/3: It’s been interesting to watch stock fluctuate on both the Nintendo Switch and the Nintendo Switch Lite over the past few weeks, and this weekend it seems like real progress is being made on the Switch Lite. We got new stock at a range of places going into the weekend, including Amazon: they won’t ship until mid month, but at least you can order them. It’s Sunday now, and you can still buy one, more or less. Some colors are sold out in their base SKU, some won’t ship until mid-month, and there are various other fluctuations in availability. But if you want to plunk down money for a Switch lite at this moment, you can do it, even at MSRP. This would suggest that resellers just aren’t having as much luck selling the Switch Lite as the standard model console. It’s still in high demand, or we wouldn’t see the scattered sellouts that we’re seeing now. But the phenomenon of not being able to find a standard Switch anywhere less then $450 or so is driven by resellers using bots to snatch up new inventory the millisecond its made available, and there just doesn’t seem to be that same level of pressure with the Switch Lite. Original Story: We’re now two-ish months into quarantine, depending on where you are, and the Nintendo Switch hasn’t gotten any easier to find. The hybrid portable/living room console became a smash hit early on as people both sought new activities to while away quarantined hours for both themselves and their children and to play Animal Crossing: New Horizons, Nintendo’s surprising smash hit life simulator. While the company is reported to be increasing production and has said that more stock is on the way, the console remains difficult to find. Here’s the truth: the Nintendo Switch is unlikely to be easy to find at MSRP for a long time now. That’s both because of the aforementioned demand and because price-gougers have taken over the marketplace using bots to snag any online availability and then shipping them over to Amazon and eBay at an inflated price point that seems to hover around $500. The problem is exacerbated by the fact that phyiscal retail is closed nearly everywhere right now, so you can’t expect to get around the bots by showing up in-person. If you live in a state where restrictions are starting to ease, there’s a chance that a retailer selling Switches might open up. Some, like Target and Walmart, have been open throughout the crisis as essential businesses, but even then stock has been near-impossible to find. As things ease up, physical retail will be an easier place to find new consoles than online, but remember to be safe, to wear a mask, and to practice social distancing. If you absolutely want a new console right now, you likely have no choice than to get one from a reseller at a significant markup. You should be reminded, however, that the base model Switch is not the only machine in this console family. Nintendo released the Switch Lite last fall, and it’s a capable little handheld. You can’t play it on the TV, and the side controllers don’t come off for multiplayer action. It’s less than ideal if you want to play Mario Kart 8 Deluxe with the family, but it’s great if you’re trying to get your kid something to do. Switch Lite comes in and out of stock from time to time, but it’s available right now at Amazon. Even if you’re remiss to get the “budget” console, it’s worth considering either for a child or for yourself. It’s more portable for anyone with a public transit commute, for one thing, and it plays everything that the Switch plays. Other than that, you’ll need to wait or shell out.

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidthier/2020/05/03/the-best-ways-to-get-a-nintendo-switch-right-now/
Rating: 4.41
Entertainment
Singular New York Steakhouse Owner Ben Benson Passes Away At 89

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

Singular New York Steakhouse Owner Ben Benson Passes Away At 89

          Ben Benson, one of New York’s exemplars in the highly competitive steakhouse genre, has died at the age of 89. Ever familiar in his brightly colored sweaters, Ben would walk slowly through his two-story restaurant on West 52nd Street, seemingly aloof. The truth was, Ben had been legally blind since college and once said, “People think I’m a snob. It’s difficult because I can’t make eye contact.”          But if he could not connect by eye with his legion of regulars, he kept his professional eye on every aspect of hospitality and quality at his restaurant, which was decked out with folk art, antlers and brass. No one bought better beef or lamb chops. His creamed spinach was nonpareil, and fried items like onion rings were irresistible once tasted. The wine list had depth and breadth and high prices, and his service staff, many long-time veterans from Eastern Europe, could carve open  a roast chicken or shell a lobster with equal parts speed and grace.           With Alan Stillman, a fellow Bucknell alumnus,  Ben founded the TGIFriday restaurants, and opened Smith & Wollensky with him on the East Side, which itself grew into a franchise chain. But Ben refused to open more than one steakhouse with his own name on it, telling the Times,  "There will never, never, never be another Ben Benson's."         Ben Benson’s Steakhouse opened in 1982 and was one of the few of its kind on the West Side, aside from the well-established Gallagher’s, which had opened in 1927. When I started frequently Ben Benson’s in the 1990s, I wrote in Esquire, “The kitchen doesn't make mistakes. There's no overpaid celebrity chef back there, just heat-hardened pros who know how to work an 800-degree grill. . . . There are no puny one and two-pound lobsters here. They start at three and go up from there: five, seven, sometimes ten.  You can spot America's best red meat-loving jocks. Former Yankee David Wells put away a double porterhouse after pitching his perfect game.  And the leakproof doggie bags, which sport a picture of BB's mascot, Rocky the bulldog.”            Ben Benson’s Steakhouse opened in 1982 and had a terrific run, but after the downturn in 2008, business slumped and never returned to acceptable heights. The steakhouse had also a lot of increased competition from newcomers on the West Side, including The Palm, Morton’s, Del Frisco’s and Ruth’s Chris. Add to that an intolerable hike in his rent, and Ben decided to close his restaurant, on Father’s Day in 2012, with vague plans to re-open somewhere else. But Ben was getting older and his sight wasn’t getting any better.           I have to imagine that Ben was a tough negotiator and taskmaster in  his business, but I only knew him as a very sweet, very New York kind of guy, ready to hear or tell a good story, eager to recommend a particular dish of the evening and someone who clearly loved what he did. That’s the way it is with true restaurateurs and why they stay in business for thirty years. Everybody knew Ben and everyone looked up to him.  There will never, never, never be another Ben Benson.

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/johnmariani/2020/05/03/singular-new-york-steakhouse-owner-ben-benson-passes-away-at-89/
Rating: 4.41
Entertainment
The Mandalorian’s Beskar Steel Has An Earthly Counterpart In Wootz Steel

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

The Mandalorian’s Beskar Steel Has An Earthly Counterpart In Wootz Steel

As the biggest Disney fan, I have long awaited the arrival of Disney+. Along with classic musicals and historic animated shorts, the platform also contains some of the biggest franchises around, including the Marvel Cinematic Universe, and of course the entire Star Wars back catalog. Launched on 24th March 2020, coinciding nicely with the start of the UK’s COVID-19 ‘lockdown’, the first thing I devoured was The Mandalorian, and with it, every Baby Yoda meme I could get my hands on. The Mandalorian is a new series set in the Star Wars universe, five years after the end of the original (and let’s just say it, best) trilogy, and two and a half decades before the latest and final trilogy of the Skywalker saga started with The Force Awakens. Din Djarin is a bounty hunter from the planet Mandalore, sporting a uniform we have seen on Boba Fett. Although they shared a job description, Fett Junior was not technically a Mandalorian. Instead, he is a clone of Jango Fett, and did not grow up on Mandalore, confirming that the way of the Mandalorian is a culture, a way of living, and not a species, race or religion. The series explores this culture in greater detail, with the famous armor playing a major role. In The Mandalorian, Djarin is paid for missions in bars of Beskar steel. This sacred material is used to make a Mandalorian’s armor, which is crafted by expert armorers that know how to work this material. Are there any parallels to materials that we know of in a galaxy closer to home? Let’s take a closer look at the material properties of Beskar steel. Beskar steel is handled as cast ingots. The dull, slate gray bars of Beskar steel have wavey ridges and patterns on the surface, and are stamped with the Imperial shield of Palpatine’s empire. Armor made of Beskar is highly sought after as it is an extremely robust material, able to withstand blaster shots and lightsaber strikes. It must therefore also be light enough to be worn for prolonged periods of time. We know that the material can be melted in a hot furnace and cast into shapes. It can be worked with heat and hammering. It is malleable enough in a thin, heated form to be shaped into panels, which make it a perfect choice for armor. Plate armor made of panels has been used for thousands of years, though the full suit of armor dates back to the Late Middle Ages. Steel, an alloy of iron and carbon, was commonly used as it can be easily forged, hammered, shaped and cut. It is also stronger than iron, owing to the fact that the carbon ‘impurities’ in the steel prevent the iron atoms from sliding past one another, giving rise to a tougher, less brittle material. Beskar certainly seems to have similar properties, and so we can presume that it is a metal, and indeed a form of steel as its name suggests. Armor needs to be light, but also strong. Sadly not enough research has been conducted on lightsabers here on Earth, so it is hard to vouch for the resistance regular steel would have against such a space sword, however it is possible to engineer steel to be reasonably blaster-proof. For example, stainless steel, an alloy of iron, carbon and some chromium, cannot catch fire easily - handy for us here on Earth, given that we cook food inside stainless steel vessels. It can therefore be presumed that Beskar steel would also be able to withstand blaster fire, especially as they tend to emit cooler yellow flames. The biggest clue as to whether there is a material analogous to Beskar steel here on Earth is the patterning on each ingot. These waves and ridges of alternating light and dark colours are a trademark of a real material that is known for its strong, light properties, just like Beskar steel. Wootz steel is a high-carbon content steel originating from south India and Sri Lanka. It is formed by heating iron ore to a high temperature in the presence of carbon-containing plants such as bamboo. The resultant smoky fire ensures a high content of iron carbide in the steel formed this way. Though iron carbide is a brittle substance, when incorporated into the bulk of the steel, it ensures that blades made of Wootz steel remain sharp. The burnt bamboo and other plant matter also imparts a little nanotechnology into the mix, ensuring that this steel is stronger and lighter than any other. Tiny nanoscopic carbon structures, such as straw-like carbon nanotubes and football-shaped fullerenes, are created in sooty fires. These nanostructures are very strong, but also incredibly light. When embedded within the steel, they make the steel even stronger, reducing the brittle nature of the steel even further, without adding any bulk. Wootz steel ingots were also used to make Damascus steel blades, which were said to be so strong, they would never shatter. Crucially however, Damascus steel and Wootz steel both display very similar wavy patterns to Beskar steel. In Wootz and Damascus steel, these patterns are formed by folding and working the steel, so that iron carbide layers line up, creating intricate patterns. These patterns were historically somewhat of a trademark, though modern techniques now allow metallurgists to create a range of bespoke and intricate designs. Although the events of the Star Wars universe took place a long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away, the science does seem to confirm that a form of Beskar steel exists in our time too. Now, if someone could hurry up with those lightsabers, it really would make my lockdown gardening so much easier...

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/sujatakundu/2020/05/03/the-mandalorians-beskar-steel-has-an-earthly-counterpart-in-wootz-steel/
Rating: 4.41
Entertainment
YoungBoy Never Broke Again Charts A Second No. 1 Album Two Months After His Last Top 10

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

YoungBoy Never Broke Again Charts A Second No. 1 Album Two Months After His Last Top 10

Rapper YoungBoy Never Broke Again surprised his dedicated legion of fans a short time ago by revealing he had a new album ready, and he dropped it on April 24 as excitement was still high. While he has always been known for his especially prolific output, it’s somewhat shocking that the musician had a new full-length prepared, as he debuted his mixtape Still Flexin, Still Steppin at No. 2 on the Billboard 200 back in February of this year. Now, he’s reached even higher, proving that there is an insatiable appetite for his art. The rapper’s new project 38 Baby 2 opens at No. 1 on the Billboard 200. The set starts with 67,000 equivalent units, and of that sum, 4,000 are pure sales, as most fans decided to stream the 17-song title. The title racked up 96.9 million streams in its first seven days of availability. 38 Baby 2 is YoungBoy Never Broke Again’s second No. 1 on the Billboard 200. He first reached the summit less than a year ago with AI YoungBoy 2, and he’s come close to adding to that total more than once. He now claims four top 10 efforts in under two years, and that’s to say nothing of his total discography, which now includes nine top 40-charters. Since 38 Baby 2 arrived with little warning, YoungBoy Never Broke Again hasn’t pushed any of the songs featured on the set to the Hot 100 just yet, though that’s likely to change. Since his stream count was so high, it wouldn’t be odd to see several cuts from the project land on the all-encompassing tally, especially since Still Flexin, Still Steppin produced at least eight charting tracks. 38 Baby 2 serves as something of a sequel to the rapper’s 2016 mixtape 38 Baby. That title didn’t chart on the Billboard 200, but it did help establish him as one of the most exciting new names in the hip-hop field. Now, just four years after the first release in the series appeared, the second is the most popular title in the country.

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/hughmcintyre/2020/05/03/youngboy-never-broke-again-charts-a-second-no-1-album-two-months-after-his-last-top-10/
Rating: 4.41
Entertainment
Ahn Jae-hong’s 2020 Film Roles Include A Funny Lawyer And A Desperate Criminal

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

Ahn Jae-hong’s 2020 Film Roles Include A Funny Lawyer And A Desperate Criminal

Ahn Jae-hong appears in two films this year and his roles in those films could not be more different. In Secret Zoo, he plays Kang Tae-soo, a probationary law firm employee, assigned to manage the Dongsan Park Zoo. The assignment is not really a favor since the zoo is broke and there are no animals to attract customers. The only solution is for the staff to dress up and pretend they are animals.  His other 2020 role is playing Jang-ho in the thriller Time To Hunt. Jang-ho is a petty criminal in a broken-down world. While his comedy character Tae-soo comes up with a desperate but hilarious scheme to keep his job Jang-ho is desperate enough to risk his life for one potentially life-changing heist. From comedy to action-packed drama, from playing a lawyer to playing a thief, both genres demonstrate his ability to create convincing characters.  “Because the two films are completely different genres I knew I had to approach them differently,” said Ahn. “With Secret Zoo, I had to win the sympathy and compassion of the audience, and with Time to Hunt, I needed to bring out extreme emotions and create a certain cinematic experience. In Time To Hunt, his character’s close friends, Joon-seok and Ki-hoon, plan to rob a gambling casino, but the plan ends with them becoming the target of a relentless assassin. Jang-ho’s only close connections in the world are doomed to endanger him. His loyalty is self-destructive. “I wanted to realistically portray the simple yet pitiful sentiment of Jang-ho’s character,” said Ahn. “I thought his reliance on Joon-seok and Ki-hoon was greater than anything, as he has no one else to turn to. He knows Joon-seok’s plan is dangerous, but for Jang-ho, not being alongside Joon-seok is meaningless. This affects Jang-ho to even lead the plan. I tried to relate to and express the desperateness of the dead-end situation.”   Before making the final decision on taking any role, Ahn notes any similarities he shares with the character. If there aren’t a lot, he considers what it will take to realize that character and Jang-ho required more than the usual amount of planning.  “I think Jang-ho and I have almost nothing in common. I felt that my approach to Jang-ho was different from how I’ve worked in the past, as I had to entirely create his personality, outer appearance, habits, and tone. However, it was similar in that it entailed the process of finding the realistic and natural aspects to be seen as the character himself.” Working with director Yoon Sung-hyun was a pleasure, said Ahn, but he also had a good time acting with his cast mates, played by Lee Je-hoon, Choi Woo-sik and Park Jung-min. “I was also grateful for and really enjoyed being able to create harmony with actors my age and whom I love.” Ahn has to date appeared in more than two dozen films, including The King of Jokgo, Microhabitat and Fabricated City. He’s also been in a handful of TV dramas, including Reply 1988, Legend of the Blue Sea, Fight for My Way and Be Melodramatic. Although his drama work has only been a fraction of his film work, his Kim Jung-bong role in the TV series Reply 1988 made the actor a household name. He didn’t plan to do more films than TV dramas. “I think it just worked out that way,” said Ahn. “I equally love both genres very much.” He continues to love acting as much as he first did during a pivotal moment in college.  “When I was 20 and in a play in college, there was this moment I felt everyone in the audience was holding their breath and completely focused on me, the actor,” he said. “I think that rush is something I’ll never forget.” For Ahn, acting is all about communicating with the audience. “I think the greatest thing about acting is that it moves the audience and brings about certain emotions within them.”  Both of his 2020 film roles accomplish that in a distinctive way.

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/joanmacdonald/2020/05/03/ahn-jae-hongs-2020-film-roles-include-a-comedy-lawyer-and-a-desperate-criminal/
Rating: 4.41

BTS Collect Another Major Honor In The U.K. With Their Latest Album

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

BTS Collect Another Major Honor In The U.K. With Their Latest Album

Like every other band and solo musician in the world, BTS can’t tour or do much to promote their most recent full-length Map of the Soul: 7 right now, but that doesn’t mean that fans everywhere aren’t consuming the project. In fact, the group’s latest CD continues to rack up healthy sales and streams in many territories, and now it has earned a special honor in one of the largest music markets on the planet. Map of the Soul: 7 has just been certified silver in the U.K. by the BPI (British Phonographic Industry), making it their latest release to secure the prize. Albums are certified by the BPI when they have hit certain sales thresholds, combining pure purchases and streaming equivalents. A silver award means the title has shifted 60,000 equivalent units. When the effort reaches 100,000 equivalents, it goes gold, and 300,000 is enough for an album to be named platinum. Map of the Soul: 7 was released back in mid-February, so the fact that it has already moved at least 60,000 equivalent copies is impressive. In fact, only a handful of albums that have dropped in 2020 have been able to reach silver status so far. BTS’s most recent project was an immediate hit in almost every country in the world, including the U.K., where it wasted no time going straight to No. 1. In doing so, it became the group’s second chart-topper, following the historic success of 2019’s Map of the Soul: Persona. The new set was preceded by the promotional single “Black Swan,” which narrowly missed out on becoming another top 40 hit by just a few rungs. First proper single “On” opened at No. 21, while album cut “Filter” barely broke through, landing at No. 100 for a single turn. Map of the Soul: 7 is BTS’s third piece of music to be certified in the U.K. this year. Just a few days into 2020, their older release Love Yourself: Tear went silver, and on the same Friday in February when Map of the Soul: 7 was made widely available, their 2019 smash single “Boy with Luv,” which features American pop singer Halsey, also earned a silver certification.

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/hughmcintyre/2020/05/03/bts-collect-another-major-honor-in-the-uk-with-their-latest-album/
Rating: 4.41
Entertainment
Box Office: 18 Years Ago, ‘Spider-Man’ Succeeded Where ‘Batman’ Had Failed

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

Box Office: 18 Years Ago, ‘Spider-Man’ Succeeded Where ‘Batman’ Had Failed

Spider-Man’s blockbuster success ushered in a new post-9/11 era of popular, present-tense comic book superhero movies with popular movie stars and based on characters audiences actually wanted to see. Today is the 18th anniversary of the opening day of Sam Raimi’s Spider-Man. The well-reviewed Marvel adaptation rode a wave of anticipation, buzz and post-9/11 populism to become the first movie to A) earn $40 million in a single day (after a $39 million Friday) and B) gross over $100 million in its Fri-Sun domestic launch. It followed up that $114 million weekend debut with a $71 million (-37%) second weekend, also a record at the time, legging out to $403 million domestic (the fifth-biggest grosser ever in 2002) and $821 million worldwide on a $130 million budget. While Batman’s blockbuster success 13 years earlier had ushered in a wave of (mostly commercially unsuccessful) period-piece pulp adventure movies, Spider-Man ushered in a new wave of big-budget, present-tense comic book superhero movies that featured characters whom audiences actually wanted to see. It was not the first comic book hit of its era, as Spawn, Blade and X-Men brought in big bucks by giving audiences comic book adaptations they actually wanted to see. But those films were either small-scale hits (Blade earned $141 million on a $40 million budget) or merely “big but not huge” earners (X-Men earned $299 million from a $75 million budget). Spider-Man, which stood out by being a coming of age romantic melodrama first and an action blockbuster second, was the first comic book superhero movie since Batman (and its three sequels) to be a true four-quadrant blockbuster. The unprecedented success of Tobey Maguire and Kirsten Dunst’s Spider-Man (inflation aside, Batman had earned $251 million from a $43 million debut, and $411 million worldwide, in 1989) sent Hollywood chasing comic book superheroes in hopes of creating the next superhero blockbuster. Perhaps because Tim Burton’s intentionally timeless Batman plays like a 1930’s pulp crime thriller, much of what arrived in the aftermath of its industry-changing success were 1920’s-1950’s pulp adventures. Walt Disney DIS ’s Dick Tracy arrived 30 years ago this June, while The Rocketeer failed to take flight that following summer. The likes of The Phantom and The Shadow typified what Hollywood tried to make in Batman’s wake, and audiences weren’t biting. That’s not a quality judgment. Dick Tracy is among the most grown-up comic book movies ever made and I’ll slam anyone who libels The Phantom. The post-Batman response was akin to Disney thinking that their live-action Dumbo remake was a surefire hit because Beauty and the Beast earned $1.263 billion. Batman was a hit because it was a star-studded and larger-than-life Batman movie, not merely because it was a pulpy superhero adventure. There were a few exceptions over the next decade. Ironically, New Line Cinema’s low-budget ($13.5 million) Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles offered exactly the right lessons from Batman’s success. It was a (very good) present-tense adaptation of a comic book/brand that was currently very popular. Star-driven vehicles like Kevin Costner’s Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves (arguably the first grimdark reboot of our time), Antonio Banderas’ The Mask of Zorro and Jim Carrey’s The Mask (which was absolutely a pulp crime comedy, but with a red-hot movie star in the lead role) were relatively big hits. New Line had such success with TMNT ($200 million in 1990), The Mask ($350 million in 1994) and Blade ($141 million in 1998) that I remain shocked that The Crow ($50 million in 1994) came from Miramax (after they grabbed it from Paramount following Brandon Lee’s on-set death). Blade and Spawn were the starting points to the second wave of superhero cinema, but X-Men (a big success predicated upon the popularity of the source material) and Spider-Man helped turn the comic book superhero movie into an A-level Hollywood franchise-creator. Contrary to popular belief, the road was not a smooth one. None of the comic book superhero movies that followed in the wake of Sony’s Spider-Man were anywhere near as huge the Sam Raimi-directed trilogy. Some of them had moderate success (Tim Story’s Fantastic Four movies both topped $300 million on over/under $115 million budgets in 2005 and 2007), but for every X2: X-Men United ($407 million on a $110 million budget), there were manylike Hulk, Ghost Rider, Punisher, Electra, Daredevil, The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen and Hellboy. Some were more successful than others, but not a one topped $250 million global. Many of the biggest success stories of the era came from comic book movies that weren’t superhero flicks (300, which earned $456 million in 2007, or Sin City, comes to mind) or were star+genre vehicles like Blade. Keanu Reeves’ Constantine earned $230 million in 2005 and remained the biggest non-Batman/Superman DC flick until Wonder Woman. Meanwhile, Daredevil sputtered at $179 million. Ghost Rider earned $226 million on a $110 million budget. Catwoman and Elektra both bombed, putting the kibosh on female-led superhero movies until Wonder Woman. Hellboy earned just $99 million, and we only got a sequel due to strong DVD sales and Universal’s desire to have a fourth big action movie in 2008 alongside The Incredible Hulk (which, irony, remains the MCU’s only bomb), Wanted (another atypical, R-rated comic book flick) and The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor. Not even Batman and Superman could measure up to Spider-Man and Wolverine. Batman Begins rode a wave of rave reviews to a frankly underwhelming $48 million Fri-Sun/$72 million Wed-Sun launch (Batman Forever had opened with $53 million in 1995) in the summer of 2005. But terrific word-of-mouth for Chris Nolan’s terrific “only slightly larger-than-life” origin story kept folks curious. It legged out to $205 million domestic and $371 million worldwide on a $150 million budget. Only solid DVD sales and a faith that an equally good sequel would uptick due to goodwill allowed what would become The Dark Knight to exist. A year later, Superman Returns would earn $206 million domestic and $391 million worldwide, but on a $260 million budget (partially due to previous development costs for discarded Superman flicks) and with none of the buzz or excitement surrounding Batman Begins. The sheer quality of Batman Begins arguably saved the comic book superhero movie as a viable genre, since up until 2008 the genre (at least in the 9/11 era) was defined by well-liked Spider-Man movies, somewhat well-liked X-Men movies and a bunch of other also-rans that couldn’t remotely compete commercially or artistically. So while Spider-Man ushered in a new era of modern-day, of-the-moment (and technology advanced) superhero adaptations, it really wasn’t until the one-two punch of Iron Man in May ($585 million worldwide) and The Dark Knight in July ($1.004 billion worldwide) that the genre truly began to artistically evolve. The “interconnected era” of the superhero movie, which would give way to The Avengers and the current dominance of the MCU, would also allow the genre to eventually diversify by approximating different genres and thus being different enough to artistically justify themselves. Batman launched a new wave of IP-specific action fantasy flicks, even if Hollywood mistook the success of Michael Keaton and Jack Nicholson’s mega-blockbuster for an inherent interest in pre/post-World War II adventure movies. Spider-Man launched a new wave of A-level superhero comic book movies, often based on comparatively modern comic books with big movie stars. But even then, Hollywood somewhat mistook the popularity of Spider-Man (based on maybe the most popular hero on Earth at the time) for an inherent interest in Marvel and DC comic book origin stories. Even Batman Begins struggled because its entire appeal was rooted in “Hey, it’s another Batman movie!” Spider-Man’s value as a high-quality, character-driven passion play (as well as a colorful action fantasy), one rooted in unapologetic sincerity, stood out in 2002 and paved the way for the likes of Captain America, Black Panther, Wonder Woman and Aquaman.

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2020/05/03/spider-man-succeeded-batman-failed-marvel-box-office/
Rating: 4.41
Entertainment
Blue’s Cool Snowball Ice Mic Is A Clear Winner All Round

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

Blue’s Cool Snowball Ice Mic Is A Clear Winner All Round

Loyal readers may know that I’m a big fan of USB Microphones. For two-way video chats and podcasting they’re absolutely brilliant. USB Mics don’t need a separate mixer or a microphone amplifier delivering 48 volts of phantom power; you simply plug them in to a Mac or PC and they just work. I’ve already reviewed some great USB mics this year from AKG and Blue and now I’m reviewing the Blue Snowball iCE cardioid mic. This is an affordable and slightly quirky USB mic that’s ideal for streaming on YouTube. The Snowball iCE is a futuristic-looking sphere that perches on a mini tripod. The sphere is made from plastic and it’s clearly been built to a price. Unlike more expensive USB microphones, the Snowball doesn’t include built-in mic monitoring, and neither does it have a mute button or controls to adjust the mic’s gain and pickup pattern. This is definitely a bare-bones mic that’s been stripped down with most of the budget being spent on the important part: the condenser capsule inside. Many USB mics also include a headphone output so that you can hear your own voice or instrument, as well as the voice of the person you’re calling or the backing track you are accompanying. These mics have zero latency mic monitoring so there’s no annoying feedback or echo that you can get with microphones relying on playback from speakers and a host computer. Built-in mic monitoring is perfect for recording multiple tracks or singing along to a backing track. Unfortunately you don't get that with the Snowball iCE so if that’s a key feature for you, maybe look at a slightly more expensive model. What you do get for your money is a superbly clear microphone that’s affordable and produces fine-quality recordings. The Snowball is ideal for laying down tracks for music projects or for recording the narration for videos. This mic is a massive upgrade on the quality of the mic built in to most laptops. However, the Snowball iCE is not so good for video chats on Facetime or other communication apps because there’s no onboard mic monitoring. This is disappointing if you are going to be hosting podcasts with online guest contributions. I tested the Snowball iCE on a video chat first because it’s labeled as being Skype Certified. I was using a pair of headphones plugged into my iMac to listen to the other person at the other end of the line so I didn’t cause any annoying feedback. I was unable to hear my own voice clearly because my ears were muffled by the headphones. And because I couldn’t hear my voice through the headphones, I ended up speaking louder than necessary because I literally couldn’t hear myself speak. Fortunately, I was still able to have a sparklingly clear conversation by removing one of the earpieces thanks to the great sound quality that the Snowball produces. The person I was talking to even commented (without prompting) on how clear I sounded and how detailed and rich the sound was. The Snowball iCE is very simple to use. All you need to do is connect it to a Mac or PC by plugging in the supplied USB Mini cable. Just ensure the Snowball is selected as the input mic in the software you’re using before adjusting the input level. In no time at all, you’ll be getting a 16-bit 48 kHz digital signal that produces great sound with very low background noise. I’ve tried other makes of microphones at this price point and most of them have has a really annoying background hiss. There’s no such problem here with the Snowball iCE Verdict: Blue’s Snowball iCE USB mic is excellent value for money. The build quality isn’t as solid as Blue’s Yeti range of mics, but the sound is exceptionally clear and finely detailed. The absence of mic monitoring is disappointing, but if you don’t need that feature then it’s a great piece of kit and perfect for YouTube streaming. However, if you do want onboard mic monitoring, I’d suggest upgrading to a Blue Yeti Nano condenser mic. Pricing: £54.99 / $49.99 / €59.99 More info: www.bluedesigns.com Specifications: Finishes: Black or white

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/marksparrow/2020/05/03/blues-cool-snowball-ice-mic-is-a-clear-winner-all-round/
Rating: 4.41
Entertainment
Ireland Will Keep Pubs Closed Until August 10 Along Its ‘Journey To A New Normal’

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

Ireland Will Keep Pubs Closed Until August 10 Along Its ‘Journey To A New Normal’

Last Friday, Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar unveiled a slow and staggered five-phase roadmap for lifting COVID-19 restrictions in his island nation, calling it a “journey to a new normal.” The prime minister’s plan lays out five stages for unlocking restrictions, at three week intervals, beginning May 18 and rolling out through most of the summer into mid-August. “As a nation, our physical health has been attacked, our mental health eroded, our economy battered, and our society put to the ultimate test,” said Varadkar in a national address, adding that stories of hardship formed a “tapestry of struggle and sacrifice and sorrow.” After taking a beating in the most recent general election, Varadkar resigned as taoiseach in February after Ireland’s parliament reached an impasse in choosing a new premier. He is currently acting as a caretaker prime minister. More recently, though, Varadkar has seen a surge in popularity for going above and beyond in his handling of the coronavirus crisis, polling suggests. A medical doctor by training, the prime minister has re-registered as a physician and committed to working one hospital shift per week for the foreseeable future. MORE FROM FORBESPhotos: Europe Starts To Reopen, But Ever So SlowlyBy Suzanne Rowan Kelleher With a population of just under five million, Ireland has confirmed over 21,000 positive cases and over 1,30o deaths due to COVID-19. The COVID-19 restrictions have been aggressive on the Emerald Isle. Since last Tuesday, Irish people have been allowed to travel up to five kilometers (3.1 miles) from home to exercise. Previously, people were limited to staying within two kilometers of home. For the time being, there is no céad míle fáilte (a hundred thousand welcomes) for would-be visitors arriving in Ireland. With the exception of people from Northern Ireland, all travelers entering Ireland must self-isolate for a 14-day period. But for anyone wondering how soon it might be safe to plan a getaway to Ireland, Varadkar’s roadmap suggests that this summer may still be pushing the envelope. Consider that Irish restaurants won’t reopen until the end of June. Hotels, museums and galleries be back in business until July 20, and pubs will remain closed until August 10. Here are some of the key milestones that would impact visitors: Beginning May 18, the first phase will allow outdoor workers to return to work and for some retail outlets such as garden centers to reopen. Some sporting and fitness activities in small groups will be permitted. People will be able to meet up to four friends and family from other households outside, while maintaining social distancing.  Starting June 8, the second phase will allow small retail outlets and markets to open where social distancing can be maintained. People can visit other households. Public libraries will reopen. On June 29, phase three begins. Cafés and sit-down restaurants can reopen where social distancing can be maintained. Non-essential retail outlets with street-level entrances and exits can open. Playgrounds will reopen. Small social gatherings can resume. With the beginning of phase four, on July 20, the tourism industry can finally begin to reopen. Hotels and hostels can open up, though initially on a limited-occupancy basis. Museums, galleries and places of worship can reopen. Want a haircut or a tattoo? Higher risk services that require direct human contact can finally resume. The fifth and final phase begins on August 10. On that date, pubs around the country can reopen and larger social gatherings can resume. Varadkar warned the Irish people that “we have not yet won this fight” and said the country would have to revert to tighter restrictions if the virus rebounded. READ MORE

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/suzannerowankelleher/2020/05/03/ireland-will-keep-pubs-closed-until-august-10-along-its-journey-to-a-new-normal/
Rating: 4.41
Entertainment
Chris Hemsworth’s Netflix Actioner, ‘Extraction,’ May Be 2020’s Only Summer Blockbuster

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • 1 articles
Weight: 2.20
Importance: 2.20
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 2020-05-03 03:00:00

Chris Hemsworth’s Netflix Actioner, ‘Extraction,’ May Be 2020’s Only Summer Blockbuster

Even if Chris Nolan's Tenet opens in July or August, Chris Hemsworth's Extraction could be the summer's only event movie for adults. With the obvious disclaimer that one should take Netflix’s own “Our new movie or TV show is a huge hit!” with a grain of salt, they are currently boasting that Chris Hemsworth’s Extraction, which debuted on April 24, is on track to nab 90 million households in its first month of availability. If that comes to pass, it’ll be Netflix’s biggest launch ever. That would be a larger viewership than Michael Bay’s 6 Underground (83 million), Sandra Bullock’s Bird Box (80 million), the first season of Henry Cavill’s The Witcher (76 million) and the Adam Sandler/Jennifer Aniston romantic comedy Murder Mystery (73 million). Of course, they now count a “viewing” as someone who watched even two minutes of a given episode or movie, as opposed to 70% (which was allegedly detrimental to the 3.5-hour-likes of The Irishman). But frankly the large viewership numbers make sense. Extraction is both a very good action movie and one of the first attempts at a Hollywood blockbuster that actually feels like a Hollywood blockbuster. Produced by the Russo Brothers and helmed by stunt choreographer and second-unit director Sam Hargave, the Chris Hemsworth action spectacular stars the once-and-future Thor as a disillusioned and borderline suicidal mercenary who kills his way across Bangladash for the sake of a kidnapped young boy. Unlike a lot of Netflix movies from a lot of really talented filmmakers (Michael Bay’s 6 Underground, Duncan Jones’ Mute, Dan Gilroy’s Velvet Buzzsaw, Dee Rees’ The Last Thing She Wanted, etc.), it feels like there was someone on set (or in development) to veto bad ideas or suggest better ideas along the way. Conversely, it doesn’t feel like a talented filmmaker crafting an adaptation that seems like the worst possible “micromanaged by executives for maximum play-ability” Hollywood redo, like Adam Wingard’s Death Note (fun fact: Wingard’s You’re Next and The Guest are terrific genre hybrids). And it’s not whatever the hell happened with Bright. It’s just a big-budget actioner with some terrific stunts and jaw-dropping set-pieces. It doesn’t reinvent the wheel and it’s a little “white savior”-ish, but it damn well works and is as confident a directorial debut as, personal preferences notwithstanding, Chad Stahelski and David Leitch’s Keanu Reeves-starring John Wick back in 2014. Moreover, by the cruelty of the current moment, I’d imagine that Extraction may continue to rack up viewership numbers for the near future. Barring a miracle, it could be this summer’s only prototypical blockbuster release. Yes, this weekend was supposed to see Scarlett Johansson’s Black Widow kicking off the summer, which is arguably why Extraction arrived on Netflix the week before (ironically one year after the $1.2 billion opening weekend of the Russo’ Avengers: Endgame). However, the summer movie season won’t really start until, at the absolutely earliest, July 17 when Chris Nolan drags us all out of our homes, gives each moviegoer a hazmat suit and personally deep-cleans every cup holder and seat in every multiplex on Earth on order to make sure that we can see Tenet as intended by God and Nolan himself. That may or may not, slight exaggerations notwithstanding, actually occur on schedule. But in terms of “big” movies that might actually open this summer, it’s Tenet, Mulan and Wonder Woman 1984. In other words, if Tenet gets delayed, then Extraction will be, by default, the event movie of the summer for adults. That’s not to say older kids can’t enjoy the R-rated and graphically violent Extraction or that the three theatrical biggies won’t be both kid-safe and adult-friendly. However, if Tenet gets delayed past Labor Day, then Extraction will be, by default, the event movie of the summer for adults. And if theaters don’t open until Labor Day, then Extraction will be the only big summer movie of the season period. That’s doubly true when you consider that the big theatrically-intended movies that ended up on PVOD (Universal’s Trolls: World Tour, Warner Bros.’ Scoob and potentially/speculatively Paramount’s SpongeBob 3) or straight-to-streaming (Disney’s Artemis Fowl) were entirely kid-targeted fantasies and not quite expected to break out. There is a cruel irony in Extraction succeeding as an old-fashioned, R-rated, star-driven Hollywood action spectacular whose kind once defined an “A-level” studio release. It likely would have garnered solid viewership anyway, but the continuing pandemic, which has left folks stuck in their homes indefinitely and kept new big Hollywood theatricals out of the multiplex, has left this it as the default summer tentpole spectacular of the season. The movie everyone hopes will jump-start the movie industry is also a ($200 million) throwback as well. All in a year where the biggest grosser is Will Smith’s R-rated throwback Bad Boys For Life. This is an odd way to celebrate the 20th anniversary of Mission: Impossible II.

2020-05-03 03:00:00 • Forbes • https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2020/05/03/extraction-chris-hemsworth-russos-netflix-chris-nolan-tenet-wonder-woman-mulan-avengers-endgame/
Rating: 4.41
